document.docAuthor: Kataev, Boris M., Wrase, David W. & Schmidt, Joachim
document.masterDocTitle: New species of the genus Chydaeus from China, Nepal, Myanmar, and Thailand, with remarks on species previously described (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Harpalini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species of the genus Chydaeus from China, Nepal, Myanmar, and Thailand, with remarks on species previously described (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Harpalini)

subSubSection.paragraph: Size. Body length 5.7–6.2 mm , width 2.6–2.8 mm ; in holotype 5.7 and 2.6 mm , respectively.
Color. Brownish black, shiny on dorsum; palpi, antennae, knees and tarsi brown; femora and tibiae almost black.

Microsculpture. Head with isodiametric microsculpture; meshes in female distinct throughout, in male distinct under and behind eyes and obliterate on remaining surface. Pronotum in male with microsculpture consisting of fine isodiametric meshes along sides and of more or less obliterate, weakly transverse meshes on remaining surface; in female with microsculpture consisting throughout of distinct, more or less isodiametric meshes. Elytral microsculpture in both sexes consisting of isodiametric meshes in narrow area along basal borders and on two lateral intervals and of weakly transverse meshes on remaining surface; meshes in male fine, somewhat obliterate, in female distinct.

Head. Comparatively large (HWmax/PWmax = 0.71–0.72 and HWmin/PWmax = 0.61–0.63 ), impunctate. Eyes small, weakly convex (HWmax/HWmin = 0.10–0.19 ). Tempora short, oblique, sloped to neck. Clypeus shallowly emarginate. Frontal foveae small, deepened; clypeo-ocular prolongations very short, usually only suggested. Clypeo-frontal suture very shallow, superficial. Supraorbital setigerous pore located at level of just behind hind margin of eyes, removed at a distance of about two diameters of pore from supraorbital furrows. Labrum shallowly emarginate apically. Apex of left mandible not truncate, only slightly blunted. Ligular sclerite almost not widened apically, truncate at apex. Antennae surpassing pronotal basal edge by approximately one apical antennomere, with narrow antennomeres 2 to 4 and rather wide (about 1.3–1.6 times as long as wide) antennomeres 5 to 10 .

subSubSection.paragraph: Elytra. Convex, oval, rounded at sides, comparatively wide [EL/EW = 1.31–1.34 ( 1.34 in male and 1.31–1.32 in female), EL/PL = 2.55–2.74 ( 2.55 in male and 2.74 in female), EW/PWmax = 1.35–1.42 ( 1.35 in male and 1.39– 1.42 in female)], widest at middle, fused along suture. Humeri subangulate, each with traces of an obtuse denticle at apex. Sutural angles less than 90 °, with apices rather sharp in both sexes. Basal borders nearly straight medially, slightly curved anteriad laterally, joined each with lateral margins at very obtuse angle. Striae impunctate, slightly crenulate, slightly impressed on disc, superficial and slightly evanescent at apex. Parascutellar strioles absent or rudimentary, parascutellar pore absent. Intervals impunctate, very slightly convex basally and flat apically. Umbilicate setal series widely interrupted at middle, consisting of five basal and eight or nine apical setae.
Hind wings reduced to very small stubs.

Legs. Metacoxae each with an additional posteromedial setigerous pore and with an additional unsetigerous fovea medially. Tarsi glabrous dorsally, tarsomere 5 with two pairs of lateroventral setae. Metatarsi shorter than HWmin, with tarsomere 1 about equal in length to tarsomeres 2 + 3 . In male, protarsi markedly enlarged, but narrower than protibia at apex (tarsomere 1 about as long as wide, tarsomeres 2–4 very short, much wider than long), and tarsomeres 1–4 with adhesive vestiture ventrally; mesotarsi weakly enlarged, narrower than mesotibia at apex (tarsomeres 1 and 2 longer than wide and tarsomeres 3 and 4 about as long as wide), and tarsomeres 2 and 3 with adhesive vestiture ventrally.
Etymology . The specific name refers to the Ganesh Himal, a mountain range in Central Nepal , where the type series was collected.

Comparative remarks . Based on characters of external morphology and structure of male genitalia,
C. ganeshensis
sp. n.
is very close to
C. minimus Kataev & Schmidt
described from the Manaslu Himal, Central Nepal . The new species differs from the latter one in the following distinctive features: clypeo-frontal suture shallower, superficial, pronotal lateral depressions absent even at basal angles, elytra wider, and metacoxae each with an oval unsetigerous fovea medially. Additionally, the male of the new species is distinguished from that of
C. minimus
by having the protarsomeres shorter, the mesotarsomeres 2 and 3 with adhesive vestiture ventrally and the median lobe of aedeagus with a more acute apex.

Distribution . This new species seems to be endemic to the Ganesh Himal, Central Nepal . Judging from the morphological similarity and the apparently allopatric distributions of
C. ganeshensis
sp. n.
and
C. minimus
, this new species seems to be a geographical vicariant of the latter.
